math_problem.A2252: Compute all ordered triples $(x, y, z)$ of real numbers satisfying the following system of equations: $$\begin{aligned} x y+z & =40 \\ x z+y & =51 \\ x+y+z & =19 \end{aligned}$$ Instead of computing all ordered triples of real numbers satisfying the system of equations, simply find $k = z + \frac{17}{5}$, where $z$ is the third component in the solution corresponding to the smaller root for $x + 1$ among the roots of the quadratic equation derived from the system.

math_problem.A2257: There are 21 competitors with distinct skill levels numbered $1,2, \ldots, 21$. They participate in a pingpong tournament as follows. First, a random competitor is chosen to be "active", while the rest are "inactive." Every round, a random inactive competitor is chosen to play against the current active one. The player with the higher skill will win and become (or remain) active, while the loser will be eliminated from the tournament. The tournament lasts for 20 rounds, after which there will only be one player remaining. Alice is the competitor with skill 11. What is the expected number of games that she will get to play?

{
  "reasoning": "Problem 1:\nWe are given the system\nxy + z = 40,\nxz + y = 51,\nx + y + z = 19.\nSubtracting the first two equations gives (y - z)(x - 1) = -11. Also, from the third equation, y + z = 19 - x. Introduce u = y - z and v = y + z so that u(x - 1) = -11 and v = 19 - x. Express y and z in terms of u and v, substitute into xy + z = 40, and then express u and v in terms of x using the two relations above. This produces a single quadratic equation in x, which simplifies to\nx^2 - 18x + 72 = 0.\nIts roots are x = 6 and x = 12, so the roots of x + 1 are 7 and 13. The smaller root for x + 1 corresponds to x = 6. Substituting x = 6 back (using y + z = 13 and y - z = -11/5) gives z = 38/5. Therefore,\nk = z + 17/5 = 38/5 + 17/5 = 55/5 = 11.\n\nProblem 2:\nReinterpret the process as follows: pick a random permutation of the 21 players (skills 1 through 21). The first in the permutation is the initial active player. Then, for k = 2 to 21, the k-th player in the permutation plays a game against the current champion; the stronger wins and remains (or becomes) champion. This is equivalent in distribution to the original “active/inactive” process. Let Alice (skill 11) be denoted A.\nIn game k (2 ≤ k ≤ 21), Alice plays if either she is the new arriving player π_k or she is the champion just before the game, C_{k-1}. Therefore, the expected number of games Alice plays is\nE[N] = sum_{k=2}^{21} P(π_k = A) + sum_{k=2}^{21} P(C_{k-1} = A).\nBecause the permutation is uniform, P(π_k = A) = 1/21 for each k, so\nsum_{k=2}^{21} P(π_k = A) = 20/21.\nNext, C_j (the champion after j players have appeared) is simply the maximum skill among the first j players of the permutation. Thus C_j = A exactly when Alice is among the first j positions and none of the 10 players stronger than her (skills 12–21) appear among those first j positions. Let there be K = 10 weaker players and L = 10 stronger players, so K + L + 1 = 21.\nTo have no stronger players in the first j positions, all L stronger players must occupy positions among the last 21 - j; this occurs with probability C(21 - j, L) / C(21, L). Conditional on this event, the first j positions are filled only by Alice and the 10 weaker players (11 total), and Alice’s position among these 11 is uniform, so the conditional probability that Alice lies in the first j is j / 11. Therefore,\nP(C_j = A) = (j / 11) * C(21 - j, 10) / C(21, 10).\nOnly j up to 11 matter because C(21 - j, 10) = 0 for j > 11. Hence\nsum_{j=1}^{20} P(C_j = A) = sum_{j=1}^{11} (j / 11) * C(21 - j, 10) / C(21, 10).\nThis sum can be simplified using standard binomial identities (a change of variables and the hockey-stick identity for binomial coefficients). Evaluating it yields\nsum_{j=1}^{20} P(C_j = A) = 1/6.\nThus the expected number of games Alice plays is\nE[N] = 20/21 + 1/6 = 47/42.\nThis is the exact expected value.",
  "answer_1": "11",
  "answer_2": "47/42"
}
